title: 114_s1550
content: The Act titled "Program Management Improvement Accountability Act" establishes governmentwide standards for program and project management in executive agencies. The Deputy Director for Management is responsible for adopting standards, policies, and guidelines, overseeing their implementation, and chairing the Program Management Policy Council. The Deputy Director for Management is responsible for establishing standards and policies for executive agencies, engaging with the private sector to identify best practices, conducting portfolio reviews of high-risk programs, and assessing the quality of program management annually. Improvement Officers assess program management quality and effectiveness, establish a 5-year strategic plan. Deadline for standards, policies, and guidelines issuance by Deputy Director for Management within 1 year of enactment. The Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with the Program Management Policy Council, shall issue regulations within 90 days to implement the requirements of section 503(c) of title 31, United States Code. Chapter 11 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include Program Management Improvement Officers and the Program Management Policy Council. Chapter 11 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include Program Management Improvement Officers designated by agency heads to implement policies and enhance the role of program managers through training and educational opportunities. Training in relevant competencies for program and project managers in the private sector, with a focus on cost containment for large projects and programs. The curr_chunk discusses mentoring, career paths, recruitment, best practices dissemination, and data analysis tools for program managers. It does not apply to the Department of Defense if similar provisions are already in place. The curr_chunk establishes the Program Management Policy Council in the Office of Management and Budget to improve agency practices in program and project management. The Council advises the Deputy Director for Management. The Program Management Policy Council advises the Deputy Director for Management on high-risk programs, workforce development, program management standards, and government-wide transparency. The Program Management Policy Council advises on program management transparency standards and reviews information on the Office of Management and Budget website. The Program Management Policy Council advises on program management transparency standards and reviews information on the Office of Management and Budget website. The Deputy Director for Management, Administrator of the Office of Electronic Government, Administrator of Federal Procurement Policy, Controller of the Office of Federal Financial Management, and Director of the Office of Performance and Personnel Management are key positions within the council. The Program Management Improvement Officer from each agency and other designated federal employees or Armed Forces members are part of the Council. The Chairperson is the Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget, with a Vice Chairperson elected by members for a term of up to 1 year. The Chairperson leads meetings, sets the agenda, directs the Council's work, and establishes subgroups as needed. The Council, led by the Chairperson, holds meetings at least twice a year to direct its work and establish subgroups. Agency heads provide administrative support as requested. A report must be submitted to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. The Officer under section 1126(a)(1) of title 31, United States Code, must submit a report to Congress containing the strategy developed under section 1126(a)(2)(B) of such title. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, is required to issue regulations identifying key skills and competencies needed for agency personnel standards. Management, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, will issue regulations to identify key skills and competencies for program and project managers, establish a new job series or update an existing one, and create a new career path for managers within an agency. The Government Accountability Office will report on the effectiveness of policies on program and project management within three years of the Act's enactment. The report evaluates the effectiveness of standards, policies, guidelines, strategic plan, Program Management Improvement Officers, and Program Management Policy Council on improving Federal program and project management.
